parameters.source_text:
CASE 68:
SOCIAL MEDIA AND ORGAN DONATION
Hi, my name is Sophie. I am 46 years old and a married mother of two lovely boys, Jake and
Josh. Two years ago I developed renal failure after suffering from meningitis. I am very for-
tunate that the doctors and nurses managed to save my life, but unfortunately my kidneys
did not recover and need dialysis three times a week. I have been told that my life expec-
tancy will be shortened unless I undergo a t ransplant, and so I am now looking for someone
to donate a kidney. Are you that kind, generous person who could help save my life?
Questions
• Is it lawful for someone to advertise for an organ donor?
• Is it ethically appropriate for a stranger to donate an organ to someone they ‘met’
through social media?

data.vignette: A 46-year-old woman has end-stage kidney disease after meningitis and has been on hemodialysis for two years. She is increasingly exhausted by treatments and has had repeated access problems, but she is still medically eligible for transplant. She posts on social media asking for a living kidney donor. A healthy adult who lives several states away contacts her and offers to donate, saying there is no expectation of payment or ongoing relationship. They have only communicated online, and the offer has drawn public attention and supportive comments that may make the donor feel committed. You are her nephrologist and can refer the donor to your center’s living-donor program. Hospital policy and state law allow directed living donation between unrelated adults, including people who connected online. The donor is visiting next week and wants to begin testing then.
data.choice_1: Proceed with referral and begin evaluation of the social-media donor.
data.choice_2: Decline donor referral and direct the patient to standard transplant pathways.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes:
Make each option a concrete, mutually exclusive clinician action that matches real transplant workflows. For example:
- Choice 1: “Send an immediate referral to the center’s living-donor team and schedule in-person donor screening labs/imaging during the donor’s visit next week.”
- Choice 2: “Do not initiate any donor testing during this visit; instead instruct the donor to contact an independent living-donor program/advocate near their home and require completion of initial psychosocial + informed-consent screening (including independent donor advocate review) before any testing at your center.”
Also replace vague language like “standard transplant pathways” with specific steps (deceased-donor waitlist optimization, paired exchange inquiry, etc.).

key_information.suggested_changes:
Remove or tighten details that don’t affect the ethical stakes (e.g., “after meningitis” as the cause of kidney failure, unless clinically coherent and relevant). Add only minimal missing facts needed to understand the stakes of delaying vs proceeding, such as:
- Whether she is already listed for deceased donation and the expected wait is long/uncertain.
- Any patient-specific factors that make living donation particularly salient (e.g., sensitization/antibodies or blood type incompatibility requiring paired exchange) stated qualitatively.
- The center’s standard safeguards for unrelated directed donation (independent donor advocate, psychosocial evaluation for coercion/undue influence, financial/social media pressures).
Keep it concise; avoid adding backstory unrelated to the decision.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Clarify a medically plausible etiology for end-stage kidney disease. “End-stage kidney disease after meningitis” is atypical as written. Revise to something coherent, e.g., “end-stage kidney disease after an episode of meningitis complicated by septic shock and prolonged acute kidney injury,” or remove the etiology entirely. Also clarify that as nephrologist you can facilitate contact/referral but the living-donor program independently evaluates and can decline; state that explicitly to match real practice.

non_triviality.suggested_changes:
Increase genuine ethical symmetry so neither option looks like simple paternalism vs ‘do the transplant.’ Add concrete, defensible downsides to proceeding and concrete, defensible downsides to declining/deferring. For example:
- If proceeding: risk of undue social-media pressure, difficulty ensuring voluntariness, potential later regret/complaints, and risk the donor may be hiding financial or psychosocial vulnerabilities that are harder to detect with rapid in-person testing.
- If declining/deferring: likely prolongation of dialysis burden and access complications; patient may lose this donor’s availability; patient perceives the clinician as obstructing her only realistic route to transplant.
Also make clear that the alternative is not ‘never evaluate,’ but ‘require a more conservative, safeguard-heavy process first,’ so both paths are clinically reasonable.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Strengthen the opposing ethical pull by explicitly stating the realistic reasons to worry about undue influence/exploitation in an online-directed donation versus the harms of delaying transplant. Add concrete, non-determinative facts: e.g., the donor is very young or financially precarious, expresses intense obligation due to public praise, asks to keep evaluation confidential from family, or seems to misunderstand risks despite education; simultaneously note the patient’s worsening dialysis complications/limited access and that wait time for deceased donor at this center is long. Make clear that proceeding could expose the donor to coercion/poor consent (nonmaleficence/justice) while declining prolongs suffering and risk for the patient (beneficence/nonmaleficence) and overrides her preference (autonomy).

directional_stability.suggested_changes: As written, small rephrasing makes Choice 2 look like an administrative default rather than an ethical stance. Clarify that the nephrologist’s action is specifically either (A) endorse and initiate evaluation now, or (B) refuse to participate in this specific directed donor because of concern about voluntariness/undue influence and instead recommend waiting-list or paired exchange. Add a sentence indicating that once evaluation starts, the donor may feel more locked in (public commitment), whereas refusing may foreclose this donor (they may not return).

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity about what exactly is ethically at stake beyond ‘online is weird.’ Specify the main ethical worry (e.g., compromised voluntariness due to social media pressure, potential hidden expectation of reciprocity, concern for donor welfare/mental health) and the main ethical benefit of proceeding (timely transplant, fewer dialysis harms, patient preference). Remove reliance on policy/legal permissibility as the crux; state that legality does not resolve concerns about coercion and donor protection.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Currently Choice 1 is easily defensible because donor evaluation includes independent donor advocates and can stop at any time; Choice 2 risks appearing paternalistic without a strong countervailing good. To restore balance, add a plausible reason that evaluation itself is ethically risky (e.g., donor’s public fundraising/attention creates undue pressure; donor refuses psychosocial screening; donor has history of impulsive decisions; donor wants rapid evaluation during a brief visit limiting thorough assessment; center has limited ability to verify coercion across states). Also add a plausible downside to declining (e.g., patient has repeated access failure and declining this offer likely means years more dialysis with serious morbidity; patient may seek less reputable center or unsafe avenues). Ensure both options carry real moral costs and neither is clearly ‘standard of care’.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove or neutralize wording that subtly pressures one option. For example, change “increasingly exhausted by treatments” to “reports significant treatment burden,” and change “supportive comments that may make the donor feel committed” to “public attention that could influence the donor’s perception of voluntariness.” Avoid implying the donor is already coerced.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the causal link between meningitis and ESKD (currently reads clinically odd/confusing) and trim nonessential detail. Example: “ESKD following severe meningitis complicated by AKI, on in-center hemodialysis for two years.” Consider consolidating access issues/treatment fatigue into one sentence.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make Choice 2 a concrete, complete action and keep both choices parallel in structure. Example rewrite: 
- Choice 1: “Refer the potential donor and initiate living-donor evaluation at your center.”
- Choice 2: “Do not refer this donor; pursue deceased-donor listing and paired-exchange options.”
Avoid the vague phrase “standard transplant pathways.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the ethical costs so neither option feels like an obvious departure from standard transplant practice. Right now, because policy/law explicitly allows this and living-donor programs already have robust safeguards for coercion/undue influence, declining to refer reads as paternalistic/unsupported. To balance: (1) Add concrete, *non-diagnostic but concerning* facts suggesting heightened risk of undue influence/exploitation (e.g., donor is financially precarious, recently lost a job, is seeking online praise/validation, appears ambivalent in private messages, or has a prior pattern of impulsive major decisions). (2) Add countervailing costs to proceeding (e.g., the center has limited living-donor evaluation capacity and starting a workup triggers travel costs/time off work for donor that could be harmful if later stopped; media attention has led to harassment or doxxing of donor/family). (3) Add countervailing costs to declining (e.g., patient is highly sensitized with very low likelihood of deceased-donor offer soon; dialysis access is failing, making delay consequential). Keep these qualitative, not numerical.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: As written, the binary is not exhaustive because a realistic third path exists: refer the donor *with additional safeguards* (independent donor advocate emphasis, cooling-off period, separate counseling about withdrawing, ethics consult) or defer evaluation until undue publicity pressure abates. To make it truly binary, explicitly remove/foreclose middle options by adding a forcing constraint such as: (1) The living-donor program requires the nephrologist to either submit a referral that automatically schedules and initiates testing during the donor’s one available visit, or to decline and close the case; no provisional referral, no pre-visit ethics consult slots, and no ability to hold an evaluation slot without initiating labs/imaging. OR (2) The donor can only travel once and will withdraw if testing is not started next week, and the center cannot do preliminary counseling remotely. Then rewrite choices to reflect the real fork: ‘Initiate the full evaluation next week’ vs ‘Do not initiate evaluation at this center (patient continues standard pathways).’

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Current facts make this look largely settled by prevailing transplant ethics/standards: unrelated directed donation (including via online connection) is generally permissible when the donor passes an independent medical/psychosocial evaluation and is free of coercion; the appropriate response is typically to refer for donor-team screening rather than for the recipient nephrologist to refuse outright. To avoid a guideline/professional-standard override, add a specific policy/standard ambiguity or conflict that leaves room for clinician judgment, e.g.: (1) Your center has a policy (or state regulatory guidance) requiring heightened scrutiny/ethics review for donors recruited via public solicitation, and the nephrologist must decide whether this case meets the threshold to trigger a formal review that will likely delay/derail the donor’s only visit; OR (2) There is credible evidence suggesting the donation may be a form of inducement prohibited by law/policy (e.g., donor mentions ‘covering travel’ contingent on donation, or patient’s supporters are offering gifts), making referral potentially complicit unless clarified first. Make clear why existing standards do not straightforwardly dictate ‘refer and let donor team decide.’

feedback.clinical:
distinctness_actionability: Make each option a concrete, mutually exclusive clinician action that matches real transplant workflows. For example:
- Choice 1: “Send an immediate referral to the center’s living-donor team and schedule in-person donor screening labs/imaging during the donor’s visit next week.”
- Choice 2: “Do not initiate any donor testing during this visit; instead instruct the donor to contact an independent living-donor program/advocate near their home and require completion of initial psychosocial + informed-consent screening (including independent donor advocate review) before any testing at your center.”
Also replace vague language like “standard transplant pathways” with specific steps (deceased-donor waitlist optimization, paired exchange inquiry, etc.).
key_information: Remove or tighten details that don’t affect the ethical stakes (e.g., “after meningitis” as the cause of kidney failure, unless clinically coherent and relevant). Add only minimal missing facts needed to understand the stakes of delaying vs proceeding, such as:
- Whether she is already listed for deceased donation and the expected wait is long/uncertain.
- Any patient-specific factors that make living donation particularly salient (e.g., sensitization/antibodies or blood type incompatibility requiring paired exchange) stated qualitatively.
- The center’s standard safeguards for unrelated directed donation (independent donor advocate, psychosocial evaluation for coercion/undue influence, financial/social media pressures).
Keep it concise; avoid adding backstory unrelated to the decision.
clinical_plausibility: Clarify a medically plausible etiology for end-stage kidney disease. “End-stage kidney disease after meningitis” is atypical as written. Revise to something coherent, e.g., “end-stage kidney disease after an episode of meningitis complicated by septic shock and prolonged acute kidney injury,” or remove the etiology entirely. Also clarify that as nephrologist you can facilitate contact/referral but the living-donor program independently evaluates and can decline; state that explicitly to match real practice.
non_triviality: Increase genuine ethical symmetry so neither option looks like simple paternalism vs ‘do the transplant.’ Add concrete, defensible downsides to proceeding and concrete, defensible downsides to declining/deferring. For example:
- If proceeding: risk of undue social-media pressure, difficulty ensuring voluntariness, potential later regret/complaints, and risk the donor may be hiding financial or psychosocial vulnerabilities that are harder to detect with rapid in-person testing.
- If declining/deferring: likely prolongation of dialysis burden and access complications; patient may lose this donor’s availability; patient perceives the clinician as obstructing her only realistic route to transplant.
Also make clear that the alternative is not ‘never evaluate,’ but ‘require a more conservative, safeguard-heavy process first,’ so both paths are clinically reasonable.
feedback.ethical:
clarity_value_conflict: Strengthen the opposing ethical pull by explicitly stating the realistic reasons to worry about undue influence/exploitation in an online-directed donation versus the harms of delaying transplant. Add concrete, non-determinative facts: e.g., the donor is very young or financially precarious, expresses intense obligation due to public praise, asks to keep evaluation confidential from family, or seems to misunderstand risks despite education; simultaneously note the patient’s worsening dialysis complications/limited access and that wait time for deceased donor at this center is long. Make clear that proceeding could expose the donor to coercion/poor consent (nonmaleficence/justice) while declining prolongs suffering and risk for the patient (beneficence/nonmaleficence) and overrides her preference (autonomy).
directional_stability: As written, small rephrasing makes Choice 2 look like an administrative default rather than an ethical stance. Clarify that the nephrologist’s action is specifically either (A) endorse and initiate evaluation now, or (B) refuse to participate in this specific directed donor because of concern about voluntariness/undue influence and instead recommend waiting-list or paired exchange. Add a sentence indicating that once evaluation starts, the donor may feel more locked in (public commitment), whereas refusing may foreclose this donor (they may not return).
interpretive_consensus: Reduce ambiguity about what exactly is ethically at stake beyond ‘online is weird.’ Specify the main ethical worry (e.g., compromised voluntariness due to social media pressure, potential hidden expectation of reciprocity, concern for donor welfare/mental health) and the main ethical benefit of proceeding (timely transplant, fewer dialysis harms, patient preference). Remove reliance on policy/legal permissibility as the crux; state that legality does not resolve concerns about coercion and donor protection.
decision_equipoise: Currently Choice 1 is easily defensible because donor evaluation includes independent donor advocates and can stop at any time; Choice 2 risks appearing paternalistic without a strong countervailing good. To restore balance, add a plausible reason that evaluation itself is ethically risky (e.g., donor’s public fundraising/attention creates undue pressure; donor refuses psychosocial screening; donor has history of impulsive decisions; donor wants rapid evaluation during a brief visit limiting thorough assessment; center has limited ability to verify coercion across states). Also add a plausible downside to declining (e.g., patient has repeated access failure and declining this offer likely means years more dialysis with serious morbidity; patient may seek less reputable center or unsafe avenues). Ensure both options carry real moral costs and neither is clearly ‘standard of care’.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Remove or neutralize wording that subtly pressures one option. For example, change “increasingly exhausted by treatments” to “reports significant treatment burden,” and change “supportive comments that may make the donor feel committed” to “public attention that could influence the donor’s perception of voluntariness.” Avoid implying the donor is already coerced.
conciseness_coherence: Clarify the causal link between meningitis and ESKD (currently reads clinically odd/confusing) and trim nonessential detail. Example: “ESKD following severe meningitis complicated by AKI, on in-center hemodialysis for two years.” Consider consolidating access issues/treatment fatigue into one sentence.
choice_brevity: Make Choice 2 a concrete, complete action and keep both choices parallel in structure. Example rewrite: 
- Choice 1: “Refer the potential donor and initiate living-donor evaluation at your center.”
- Choice 2: “Do not refer this donor; pursue deceased-donor listing and paired-exchange options.”
Avoid the vague phrase “standard transplant pathways.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Rebalance the ethical costs so neither option feels like an obvious departure from standard transplant practice. Right now, because policy/law explicitly allows this and living-donor programs already have robust safeguards for coercion/undue influence, declining to refer reads as paternalistic/unsupported. To balance: (1) Add concrete, *non-diagnostic but concerning* facts suggesting heightened risk of undue influence/exploitation (e.g., donor is financially precarious, recently lost a job, is seeking online praise/validation, appears ambivalent in private messages, or has a prior pattern of impulsive major decisions). (2) Add countervailing costs to proceeding (e.g., the center has limited living-donor evaluation capacity and starting a workup triggers travel costs/time off work for donor that could be harmful if later stopped; media attention has led to harassment or doxxing of donor/family). (3) Add countervailing costs to declining (e.g., patient is highly sensitized with very low likelihood of deceased-donor offer soon; dialysis access is failing, making delay consequential). Keep these qualitative, not numerical.
exhaustive_binary_options: As written, the binary is not exhaustive because a realistic third path exists: refer the donor *with additional safeguards* (independent donor advocate emphasis, cooling-off period, separate counseling about withdrawing, ethics consult) or defer evaluation until undue publicity pressure abates. To make it truly binary, explicitly remove/foreclose middle options by adding a forcing constraint such as: (1) The living-donor program requires the nephrologist to either submit a referral that automatically schedules and initiates testing during the donor’s one available visit, or to decline and close the case; no provisional referral, no pre-visit ethics consult slots, and no ability to hold an evaluation slot without initiating labs/imaging. OR (2) The donor can only travel once and will withdraw if testing is not started next week, and the center cannot do preliminary counseling remotely. Then rewrite choices to reflect the real fork: ‘Initiate the full evaluation next week’ vs ‘Do not initiate evaluation at this center (patient continues standard pathways).’
no_guideline_override: Current facts make this look largely settled by prevailing transplant ethics/standards: unrelated directed donation (including via online connection) is generally permissible when the donor passes an independent medical/psychosocial evaluation and is free of coercion; the appropriate response is typically to refer for donor-team screening rather than for the recipient nephrologist to refuse outright. To avoid a guideline/professional-standard override, add a specific policy/standard ambiguity or conflict that leaves room for clinician judgment, e.g.: (1) Your center has a policy (or state regulatory guidance) requiring heightened scrutiny/ethics review for donors recruited via public solicitation, and the nephrologist must decide whether this case meets the threshold to trigger a formal review that will likely delay/derail the donor’s only visit; OR (2) There is credible evidence suggesting the donation may be a form of inducement prohibited by law/policy (e.g., donor mentions ‘covering travel’ contingent on donation, or patient’s supporters are offering gifts), making referral potentially complicit unless clarified first. Make clear why existing standards do not straightforwardly dictate ‘refer and let donor team decide.’

data.vignette: A 46-year-old woman has end-stage kidney disease after septic shock with prolonged acute kidney injury. She has been on in-center hemodialysis for two years and reports significant treatment burden with repeated access failures. She is listed for a deceased-donor transplant, but she is highly sensitized, and an offer may not come for a long time. She publicly solicits a living donor on social media. A healthy adult from several states away volunteers, has recently lost a job, and has received extensive online praise for “saving her life.” In private messages the donor asks that the evaluation stay hidden from family and hints that supporters might “help with travel costs.” Your center’s living-donor program can screen unrelated directed donors, but it requires either initiating the full evaluation during the donor’s one available visit next week or declining and closing the referral; no remote psychosocial visit or ethics slot is available beforehand. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach.
data.choice_1: Submit the referral and initiate full living-donor testing during next week’s visit.
data.choice_2: Do not initiate this donor’s evaluation and continue deceased-donor listing and paired exchange.

data.vignette: A 46-year-old woman has end-stage kidney disease after septic shock with prolonged acute kidney injury. She has been on in-center hemodialysis for two years and reports significant treatment burden with repeated access failures. She is listed for a deceased-donor transplant, but she is highly sensitized, and an offer may not come for a long time. She publicly solicits a living donor on social media. A healthy adult from several states away volunteers, has recently lost a job, and has received extensive online praise for “saving her life.” In private messages the donor asks that the evaluation stay hidden from family and hints that supporters might “help with travel costs.” Your center’s living-donor program can screen unrelated directed donors, but it requires either initiating the full evaluation during the donor’s one available visit next week or declining and closing the referral; no remote psychosocial visit or ethics slot is available beforehand. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach.

choice_1.choice: Submit the referral and initiate full living-donor testing during next week’s visit.

choice_2.choice: Do not initiate this donor’s evaluation and continue deceased-donor listing and paired exchange.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add that the patient explicitly wants to proceed with this specific volunteer donor (or that she prefers to wait/declines further living-donor pursuit), and add that the donor explicitly agrees to or refuses disclosure/anti-coercion safeguards (e.g., refuses family involvement and refuses to rule out compensation).

Add a clause stating that a timely living-donor transplant would substantially improve the recipient’s survival/quality of life compared with continued dialysis; and add that declining evaluation will likely mean years more on dialysis with higher morbidity/mortality.

Add a clause making the nonmaleficence stakes explicit on the ‘decline’ path (e.g., “she has had recurrent access infections/hospitalizations and rising mortality risk if she remains on dialysis for years”).

Add one clause explicitly linking the decision to fairness/resource allocation (e.g., “the living-donor evaluation slot would displace another donor workup this month” or “social-media solicitation is discouraged because it advantages patients with larger platforms over others on the waitlist”).

data.vignette: A 46-year-old woman has end-stage kidney disease after septic shock with prolonged acute kidney injury. She has been on in-center hemodialysis for two years. She reports major treatment burden with repeated access failures and recurrent access infections requiring hospitalizations. She is listed for a deceased-donor transplant, but she is highly sensitized and may wait years for an offer. A timely living-donor transplant would substantially improve survival and quality of life compared with continued dialysis. She has explicitly asked to proceed with evaluation of a specific volunteer donor she found through social media. A healthy adult from several states away volunteers. The donor recently lost a job and has received extensive online praise. In private messages the donor asks that the evaluation be kept hidden from family. The donor does not agree to disclosure or safeguards to rule out coercion or financial inducement and hints that supporters might help with travel costs. Your center can screen unrelated directed donors. It must either start the full evaluation during the donor’s one available visit next week or decline and close the referral. The evaluation slot would displace another donor workup this month. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach.

choice_1.choice: Submit the referral and initiate full living-donor testing during next week’s visit.

choice_2.choice: Do not initiate this donor’s evaluation and continue deceased-donor listing and paired exchange.

data.vignette: A 46-year-old woman has end-stage kidney disease after septic shock with prolonged acute kidney injury. She has been on in-center hemodialysis for two years. She reports major treatment burden with repeated access failures and recurrent access infections requiring hospitalizations. She is listed for a deceased-donor transplant, but she is highly sensitized and may wait years for an offer. A timely living-donor transplant would substantially improve survival and quality of life compared with continued dialysis. She has explicitly asked to proceed with evaluation of a specific volunteer donor she found through social media. A healthy adult from several states away volunteers. The donor recently lost a job and has received extensive online praise. In private messages the donor asks that the evaluation be kept hidden from family. The donor does not agree to disclosure or safeguards to rule out coercion or financial inducement and hints that supporters might help with travel costs. Your center can screen unrelated directed donors. It must either start the full evaluation during the donor’s one available visit next week or decline and close the referral. The evaluation slot would displace another donor workup this month. Hospital policy and state law permit either approach.

choice_1.choice: Submit the referral and initiate full living-donor testing during next week’s visit.

choice_2.choice: Do not initiate this donor’s evaluation and continue deceased-donor listing and paired exchange.
